passage.text: Man is timid and apologetic; he is no longer upright; he dares not say 'I think,' 'I am,' but quotes some saint or sage. He is ashamed before the blade of grass or the blowing rose. These roses under my window make no reference to former roses or to better ones; they are for what they are; they exist with God to-day. There is no time to them. There is simply the rose; it is perfect in every moment of its existence. Before a leaf-bud has burst, its whole life acts; in the full-blown flower there is no more; in the leafless root there is no less. Its nature is satisfied, and it satisfies nature, in all moments alike. But man postpones or remembers; he does not live in the present, but with reverted eye laments the past, or, heedless of the riches that surround him, stands on tiptoe to foresee the future. He cannot be happy and strong until he too lives with nature in the present, above time.

Okay, cool. We’ll go back to that later. For now, let’s do some Zincing.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Zincing
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Reading is different from other medias. With video, it puts images directly into your brain, but when you read, there’s an extra step. You have to turn sentences and words into images in your mind. This is what we call Zincing. Not Zincing is like playing a video game with your eyes closed. The text may as well be a solid rock wall. Picture words are handholds that help you climb the rock wall. Zincing is the only way to understand and appreciate good writing.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Visualize
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Your first Zincing move is always to look for words or phrases that you can easily picture. Good writers will give you that, so you can always find those.

video.transcript: Yeah, that works. Good job picturing the whole phrase - not just some guy, but also how he’s acting.
Yeah. I can picture a guy here, but what about him? Highlight the whole phrase.
Yeah. I can picture a guy here, but what about him? Highlight the whole phrase.

onCorrectMessages.transcript: Cool. Now highlight two more things you can easily picture.

onInCorrectMessages.transcript: Hm...we didn’t think that was easy to picture. Try again.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Plenty to visualize here! Highlight something in the first sentence you can easily picture. Remember to picture the whole phrase.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Key Images
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Some image words just describe stuff the writer wants you to picture. For example, “the beetle crossed the road.” You see a beetle, you see a road. Done. But great writers can also use words to describe much more. “The beetle skittered across the road like a child on her way to the first day of school.” When I get an image like that, the first thing I have to do is picture it. For me, I see maybe skittering legs on the pavement or maybe I think of my first day of school...or, I mean, anything really that you associate with the first day of school and the verb skittering. To fully understand an image, you have to picture it, but also understand where it takes your mind.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: What’s the strongest image for you? Which one jumps out at you or tells you something important? Remember there’s no one right answer.

highlight.text: stands on tiptoe to foresee the future

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Why is man on tiptoe? Emerson could have just said, “He’s always trying to see the future” or “He’s worried about the future.” How does saying that man “stands on tiptoe” change the meaning? What feeling does “stands on tiptoe” convey?

sceneLoadVideo.label: Imagine
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Sometimes a writer can say something without giving a specific visual. “She was competitive and clever.” What does that mean? For me, the first thing that came to mind was maybe someone in a debate or spelling bee. Come up with something that makes sense to you and keep reading to find out more.

highlight.text: He is ashamed before the blade of grass or the blowing rose.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Just to be clear, “before” used to mean “in front of, “ so, “He is ashamed before the blade of grass or the blowing rose,” means the man feels ashamed in front of the blade of grass or the blowing rose. What??? What could Emerson mean here? More on this later, but why would a person feel ashamed in front of a plant? If you have an idea, type it in the chat. Otherwise, click “I don’t know,” and see if Emerson explains.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Navigators
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: When you’re driving, everything from stop lights to brake lights to the paint on the street tells you how to navigate. Ignoring these could cause a dangerous crash. No one gets physically hurt when you ignore navigation signals in a text, but your comprehension gets run over.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Road Signs
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: When you read, basic road signs include punctuation or transition words. For example, commas, dashes, periods, semicolons -- any punctuation that you can think of. Or transition words like because, although, also, in addition. They direct your reading. They say things like, keep going, go in a new direction, or here’s an explanation.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Pronouns
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Pronouns are words like he, she, it, those, which, that, these. When you see them in a text, they always refer to something. They usually refer to something that’s been mentioned or something that’s going to be mentioned. That is the first thing you have to do when you see a pronoun: find what it refers to.

wrongAttemptMessages.transcript: Nah. Try again. Who does the “he” refer to?

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Who is the “he” in the first two sentences? Drag “he” to the word it replaces.

onFinish.transcript: Nice. You may already know this, but back in the 1800s, when Emerson wrote this, they referred to humans or a person as “man” or “mankind.

onFailure.transcript: Hmmm… Maybe watch the Pronouns video and then give this another shot.

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Cool. Next, Emerson talks about roses. He uses three different pronouns to refer back to “these roses” or “the rose.” Drag “roses/the rose” onto each of the three pronouns that represents them.

sceneLoadVideo.label: Explainers
sceneLoadVideo.transcript: A big part of what writers do is explain. They say something, often something that you don’t fully understand, and explain it by giving details, an explanation, etc, a lot of things that will help you get what they mean. Punctuation often acts as a road sign to let you know when an explanation is coming. Keep an eye out for an explanation and make sure to connect it back to the phrases that it explains.

options.label: Like roses, people experience different stages of life, but roses need water and sunlight to thrive
To live a good life, people need to stop worrying about the past and the future and appreciate the present
People need to work and make money, whereas roses get by with a little sunshine
Since time has no beginning and no end, we need to concern ourselves with only the small piece of time we experience
Small things in life, like roses or a delicious meal, are what matter most - not fame or wealth

sceneLoadVideo.transcript: Okay, good. So which of these do you think best sums up the main idea?
